Old-timey spinneh watchmaker's cleaning machine. One jar with Elma 1:9 then two naphtha rinses. I wish I could find a non-flammable rinsing fluid.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17481745
There are people out there that used water-based washing fluids like deox-007, but you have to be careful to immediately dry/rinse the parts. I don't want to think about that so have stayed away from aqueous solutions for watches, but have used that for cleaning a clock movement where it's easier to dry the parts immediately with a compressed air stream.
I stay away from anything ammoniated; I tried that first and noticed it pulled some of the copper out of surface of the parts. Did some research after that and found that it embrittles the metal on prolonged exposure, so switched to plain naphtha.

Yes.

1) I hate fashion. I'm only posting because I saw the thread on the front page and I can write something relevant. Indoors, I keep a pair of indoor-only sandals, for multiple reasons. Like my outdoor sandals (everytime except winter, with snow on the ground), I always wear whatever pair of sandals I have on with black socks. This allows my feet to breath and keeps my eczema in check, and the layer of the sock is a skin which protects against infection and injury. This functionality is far more important than any fashionable consideration could ever possibly be.

2) Certain of my neighbors are zero-conscientousness democrat voting assholes who insist on a) keeping a dog even though no one ever held a gun to their head forcing them to keep a pet while b) not being fucked to curb their stupid animal in winter. The landlord appears to have issued an ultimatum, and this won't get anyone to exhibit basic human decency, so they'll simply get fined I suppose. While I realize that my willingness to live in such a place speaks as much to my own stupidity as it does to theirs, they're the ones leaving turds.

I'm taking one for the team:

Okay, let's make it simple!

To dress like a gentleman, you want to wear clothes that look polished and put-together. That means avoiding anything too casual, like ripped jeans or athletic wear.

Here's what you can wear for different occasions:

A casual day out:
For a more relaxed look, you can wear a pair of chinos (a type of pants), a button-down shirt, and some sneakers or loafers.

Office workday:
For a more professional look, you can wear a dress shirt, a tie, dress pants, and dress shoes. A blazer or a suit jacket can also be added for extra formality.

Formal events:
For a formal event, you can wear a suit (jacket and pants made from the same material), a dress shirt, a tie, and dress shoes.

To shop for these clothes, you can visit men's clothing stores in your local mall or online retailers that sell men's clothing. Look for brands that are known for producing high-quality, timeless clothing.

Remember, dressing like a gentleman is not just about what you wear, but also how you wear it. Make sure your clothes fit you well, and that you feel comfortable in them. With a little bit of effort, you'll be able to dress like a gentleman in no time!

for pants, chinos are always a good pick. they can easily be dressed up or down and are readily available. for shirts, button ups and polos are your friend. for long armed button ups, spend some time trying to find ones that fit you well. if you have an athletic frame, go for flattering but never tight. make sure they fall nicely when tucked in to your pants. i can't stress enough how important proper sizing is for button ups. polos are less sensitive to that. over your shirt, wool sweaters are a great choice. troyers and v necks allow the collar to stand naturally with the uppermost button undone giving you a more sporty, casual appearance. troyers are more sporty than v-necks. crew necks will give collars a more restrained look. be careful with that, it can make you look very boyish depending on how masculine you look to begin with and the type of collar you wear. i prefer wool sweaters over cotton. for shoes, i like chucka boots. leather boots in general will work. if you live in the city, you can easily do dress shoes too.

AM:
Rinse face with water (do not dry)
Cetaphil cleanser applied to damp face
Rinse face with water (do not dry)
Cetaphil moisturizer applied to do face
Any SPF 50+ sunscreen once face has dried

PM:
Rinse face with water (do not dry)
Cetaphil cleanser applied to damp face
Rinse face with water (dry it this time)
Apply tretinoin (no, it is not too harsh)
Wait 15 minutes
Wet hands, apply Cetaphil moisturizer

This will get you 90% to the best skincare routines, and the cost is cents per day.

Other tips:
Do not touch your face unless you wash your hands.
Do not let a used towel touch your face.
Buy 10 of the cheapest cotton pillow slips (they are usually less than a dollar each) and change nightly.
Drink enough water.
When you are in the sun, wear a hat.
Remember that leathery skin is your body's way of protecting itself from sun, that means good looking skin is inherently more vulnerable to sun, beware the sun.

Depends on the type of leather boot you want.
>Hiking
Get some lace-to-toe leather boots instead of combat boots. Your feet will thank you. The ability to choose the lacing the whole way up the foot is a huge plus.

They're more expensive for sure, but you pay for more boot. They'll typically last longer and take more punishment. Danner makes the Mountain Light hiking boots, which are ~$400. If that's too expensive, Chippewa makes their roofer boots which are the same concept for ~$250. Georgia boots are cheaper with their logger lace-to-toe boots at ~$180

Obviously wash your feet every day. Put talcum powder in your socks or on your feet. Then let your shoes air out for 10 minutes when you take them off, then put in shoe trees. Don't wear them every day.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17477879
The mistake you're making is wearing the same pair of footwear 24/7 and expecting them to be fine. They won't.
You need at least two pairs in a rotation, or 3 if you really have a acid monkey sweat problem. Some people do as their body chemistry is overwhelmingly low ph for some reason.
Two/three pairs of whatever, when you take off a pair let it dry for a bit, longer if you're in a cold and wet environs where things don't try easily on their own, then slip in some shoe/boot trees. Cedar wood preferred. The next day you DON'T wear that pair, and instead wear the other pair. Repeat the cycle.
Avoid leather soles if you're worried about speedy wear. Shouldn't use leather soles in wet conditions anyway as they deteriorate 10x faster when wet.
Get more than one pair of whatever it is.

If you're talking about building a wardrobe out of stuff you can't afford, just look for cheaper versions. In this day and age you can find almost any item in every price range.

If you're talking about one specific item, save for it. It might take you longer than you wanted, but it'll be worth it.

But maybe the first thing is to reevaluate why you want something. I've been guilty -and still am, sometimes- of vapid consumerism when buying something more for the thrill of getting ot than from actually wearing the item later.
I've been tempted to get rid of most of my stuff and keep a minimalistic wardrobe, but more often than not can't part with stuff even if I've not worn it for long and probably won't wear it ever again.

This is completely wrong.
pre-natal T affects primarily brain development in the embryo and in infancy, especially high or low T in the womb is associated with abnormal sexual development and alternative gender identities
post-natal T affects physical characteristics after puberty.
regular T affects muscle growth, bone growth, fertility, and sex drive
the DHT metabolite (other major form of T in humans) affects genital growth, hair growth (balding on the head, body hair growth), and is the key male neurosteroid, driving behaviors like aggression and competition.

>>17482045
It definitely is.

Any recommendations for treatment/prevention?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17482136
Get it wet and saturate the stain with dish soap. The standard blue Dawn one works best, but Palmolive or other plant-based ones are usually enough for most oil stains too. Rub it in good and soak it in a container/sink/bowl full of water with the dish soap anywhere from an hour to overnight.

Machine wash as usual after that and it should be gone. For tougher stains that have gone through the dryer or been ironed in, follow the dish soap soak with another soak in Oxiclean or any generic sodium percarbonate-based “non chlorine bleach” for another 1-8 hours and wash.

If that STILL doesn’t work (and it will for most oil/grease stains) you can try spraying it with an enzyme-based stain remover and let it sit for up to a week and then wash.

If all else fails, you can take it to the cleaner and pay $10 to have a professional take care of it. But usually a combination of dish soap > oxiclean > enzyme spray (in order of harshness) is more than enough to get rid of food stains. Usually the Dawn alone is enough.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Fashion is a competition of ridiculousness. What is fashionable is ridiculous, and what is ridiculous can be fashionable. What is ridiculous differs from era to era, thus there always being a disjunction in fashion taste from generation to generation. The younger generation adopts what the prior generation considers ridiculous as a gesture of rebellion. The older generation laughs at the younger generations ridiculous fashion sense, despite it being what is fashionable. You can notice this in fashion shows, where the ridiculousness is turned up a notch. What is ridiculous catches the eye due to its uncommonness, and by the time it becomes common, it is no longer ridiculous. To be fashionable: appear ridiculous, and be praised for it.

To expand on what is ridiculous, it can be a play on any of the following:

weird proportions
striking colors, material or patterns
throwbacks to older eras
asymmetry


Having exhausted all the proportions and textures, the current trajectory of fashion is toying with a fundamental aspect of reality: Shape.

>>17478911
Sotd Guerlain Coriolan
Cariolan is a men’s fragrance, presented in 1998 in a woody chypre composition. It is dedicated to the man full of contrast: to Coriolan, a legendary Roman general who was said to be powerful and strong, pride and confident, barer of nobility, braveness and love. Coriolanus has inspired Shakespeare, Plutarh and Beethoven. He was the man who accomplished all of his goals, not because of his glory, but because of a woman he loved. The character of this great man inspired Jean-Paul Guerlain to make this fragrance; to celebrate freedom of the spirit and love with carnal pleasures and seduction. The perfume is made out of lemon leafs, bergamot, neroli and petit grain at the top notes, its heart ticking in a passionate rhythm of spicy fusion of ginger, nutmeg, ylang-ylang and gorse; settling at the warm woody base of patchouli, benzoin and leather. The elegant glass bottle was designed by Jean-Paul Guerlian in association with Robert Granai. The top and the curves on the side of the bottle are made out of bronze.

>>17480320
Fahrenheit plays on hot and cold tones within it’s main structure, fusing a cool floral top with a warm woodsy middle, a base of green leather and tonka, plus that all-powerful X factor no other fragrance has, nor even can have, because the creation of Fahrenheit’s most characteristic quality was a total accident. Michael Almairac, Maurice Roger, and Jean-Louis Sieuzac were all competing perfumers working on primitives to win the bid fo the next masculine Dior fragrance, but none had their idea accepted by the design house, and tossed their samples all in the same waste barrel for disposal. As fate would have it, that barrel sat out in the sunlight for a while and fused together, essentially “cooking” into one, and when somebody returned to find the barrel still there, the smell that came off was evidently so captivating that Dior had chemists analyze a sample of it so the perfumers could form a new composition around it as the base! The infamous “barrel note” is really just leather and a strong violet at it’s core, which is the root cause for the petrol smell everyone comments on when they sniff the opening of Fahrenheit, but there’s a mish-mash of whatever else was in those original perfume formulas in there too, cooked up and reduced in a way only nature could, so it’s impossible to replicate without having the formula gleaned from the sample’s analysis. The rest of Fahrenheit is more or less the same late 80’s men’s floral ya-ya that everyone was doing right before the age of aquatics when calone and dihydromyrcenol took over as the chemistry du jour, and is one of few such floral powerhouses from the era still available.

The dragon is very gay, even in how he writes, similar to most of the faggots here. But at least the dragon is knowledgeable. Good find about Fahrenheit, I believe it. Here is gay dragons review or l’anarchist. He noted on the warm cool dichotomy here too.
>The opening of L'Anarchiste is a big blast of peppermint, almost at medicinal levels of menthol, with what feels like some camphor too. Anyone who's smelled Avon Windjammer (1968) or the "steel" component of the Avon Structured for Man (1969) vanity set knows what I mean. Bracing, cold, metallic, and masculine is this opening. Richard Fraysse softens this opening just a bit with mandarin and neroli, more so in the black bottle re-issue than in the original copper-color bottles according to the house itself, due to backlash over the original formula's opening; but the citrus and neroli is in both iterations. The heart of lavender, cinnamon and clove does remind me a bit of Le 3ème Homme (1985), Fraysse's previous masculine for Caron with Akiko Kamei, but the resemblance is fleeting once a dry pencil shavings cedar takes over. A sandalwood note (of some fashion), and white musk smooth out the dry down, while vetiver smoke also weaves in to darken the finish. The final aura of L'Anarchiste is cold, metallic, smokey, synthetic, brooding, but also with enough warmth and sweetness to project off skin rather than fade like the old colognes and aftershaves it models. L'Anarchiste is the anti-establisment robotic parody of the square-jawed clean-shaved slicked-hair white male paradigm of 1950's masculinity, or the band Devo in scent form. Wear time is about 6 hours so longevity is a tad sub-par, but you won't want for projection. Best use is basically whenever, because L'Anarchiste is too bizarre for contextual appropriateness. The minty personality also makes L'Anarchiste a poor winter companion, but the other three seasons seem to work well for the stuff.

>>17480504
It is bull shit. The International Fragrance Association (((IFRA))) is a self-regulatory body comprised of fragrance companies around the world. It aims to gatekeep who can sell fragrances, and to develop standards and regulations for the industry. The IFRA sets standards for the use of fragrance ingredients and provides guidelines to its members. The organization has the power to enforce its rules through its members, who agree to comply with its standards as a condition of membership. The (((IFRA))) sets standards for the use of fragrances in products, but they are not a regulatory body with the power to enforce their standards. Companies that do not comply with IFRA standards may face difficulty selling their products to customers or distributors who only want to work with products that meet these standards. However, the (((IFRA))) standards are not legally binding and companies may choose to disregard them if they so choose. The consequences of non-compliance would depend on the specific circumstances and may vary depending on the country and industry. For example, the (((European Union))), require that fragrances used in personal care and household products comply with IFRA standards. So basically the (((EU))) is cucking the whole industry.

>>17480952
ignore that other nigga
Luna rossa black is often compared to midnight in paris by van cleef though I have NO idea how people have not made that comparison with luna rossa extreme instead, since it's way closer to midnight in paris than LR black.
LR Black is amazing, though not everyone is going to like it because it has that really musky smell of like, fresh tennis balls. I love it and it's my signature desu.
LR carbon is like soapier more metallic sauvage. Personally I like sauvage more, but its not terrible and worth sampling if you kinda like sauvage.
Original luna rossa smells like musky orange soap. Not much to say but I like it as a dumb grab when I just want to smell like detergent.
LR Sport is similar to carbon in the sense that LR sport is basically le male but soapier. I prefer LR sport over le male but I love both pretty equally and le male comes off as more masculine.
Eau sport is just kinda a basic clean citrusy freshie that is pretty unremarkable desu.
As you could probably tell, the luna rossa line is pretty musk forward, aside from eau sport and carbon, and prada likes to make their perfumes (both male and female) pretty soapy and clean. It is one of my favorite lines and I highly recommend LR black, sport, and the OG luna rossa.

LR ocean is trash, not even sure what happened it just smells bad. other reviews have confirmed my opinion on it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
What does /fa think of perfume alternatives like roll on oils or solid colognes?
I personally prefer roll ons since they tend to last longer while having a less obnoxious throw. I also like that it gets stronger with sweat/body heat so it's like an adaptive defense against sweat smells. Big downside is that the only source for them is random people trying to mimic the top shelf frags, but I've actually found some diamonds. There was this small seller on etsy who used to make a spicebomb imitation that I actually preferred to the real thing.
With that in mind I've decided to give making my own oil a go, since I know what perfumes I like, it would be cool to make a signature scent that's unique to what you can buy.

>>17479820
Retinoids should be used at night not because they make your skin sensitive to UV, but because the retinoid itself is sensitive to UV and will become chemically unstable/break down before it's able to work if exposed to daylight. (And temperature. Keep your retinoid/retinol products in the fridge where possible. Otherwise a dark drawer or cupboard.)

Morning:
>Cleanse.
>Toner (pref. Korean or otherwise astringent free.)
>Active serum (if applicable.)
>Moisturizer/cream (your hyaluronic acid/niacinamide cream.)
>Sunscreen.
Night:
>Cleanse.
>Toner.
>Retinol/Retinoid product. Leave for 10-15 minutes to fully absorb.
>Serum.
>Moisturizer/cream.

Once a week take a break from the retinol to use a clay mask and then a hydrating mask (substitute the retinoid's place in your routine and use the other products as normal.)

If you use an off-the-shelf retinol/retinoid product, you can still use a chemical exfoliant like AHA once a week, also. Don't do this with a prescription strength retinoic acid.

If you find your skin is very sensitive at the beginning, ease into the retinoid by using it every second day, then two days on/one day off, and build up to using it every day. It can help.


>>17479842
Wash your pillowcase every week, pay attention to what touches your face during the day, consider a new shampoo/conditioner and your diet. Excess sugars fuck with your hormones and skin.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17479826
Just because I forgot to tag (you) specifically: Yes. Once a week replace the retinol with a ~10% lactic acid solution. This will go a lot better for your skin if you wash with a microfibre cloth and avoid ever swiping/scrubbing your face with a towel. Always pat, because once you introduce this level of chemical exfoliant you want to avoid physical exfoliation as much as possible.

I find that a thick wash-off mask with a strong anti-inflammatory active ingredient really helps once you have this level of exfoliation happening. The Some By Mi Propolis B5 mask is my favourite. An anti-inflammatory sleeping pack would probably be great, too.

>>17479715
I wouldn't call them bold but neither would call them cringe.

IRs are baby's first real boot for a lot of people. As an entry level boot they're avobe malltier shit (including docs and solovairs) in terms of looks and quality. They're populaar for several reasons.
In the looks department they have this mixture of ruggedness and slickness that makes them versatile for everyday wear. They look less bulbous and bulky (i.e. clown shoes) in person than in pics. Paired with non cuffed jeans they look very understated.
In terms of quality the construction and materials look and feel so much better than the malltier boots people are accustomed to, so as a newbie to boots you feel you're getting a lot of shoe for the price.
Regarding price, they're still in the affordable category. Not many people wpuld go from spending 80-100 on shoes to dropping 7-800 on some pnw boot or something similar, but would make the leap to 300-350 if they want a higher quality boot.
And lastly, but not least, compared to similar boots, they have a shorter break in period, which makes them more newbie friendly.
To sum it up, while far from the endgame in terms of boots, they fill a wide niche and most people don't actually need more boot than IRs, unless you want something dressier, I guess.
/fa/ loved them back in the 2010's but hates them now because they got popular and reddit lives them. And hating on whatever is popular or reddit does is 4chan's understanding of what being a contrarian is. Contrarianism for the sake of it with no more thought put on it than the trendhoppers on reddit.

Let’s not get lost in the weeds. First off I think you have to be more specific, and carve just the northeast portion off the USA and compare only that part to the UK. Otherwise it’s not a fair comparison at all because the rest of the country is a mess fashion wise, and yes that ESPECIALLY includes LA and Miami (you can’t buy class). With that out of the way, the UK is still the clear winner. Hopefully this doesn’t offend American anons, but I think it’s just because the USA is a younger country and hasn’t reached the same level of civilization yet. American style is simple and utilitarian. Think Ralph Lauren, Brooks Brothers etc. This is actually more aligned with my own personal style. Old Europe is just gay to me. America hasn’t gone through as many cycles of decadence as older countries have. I think this is changing and you can see it in things like the craft beer trend, “foodie culture”, and increased wine and quality cheese production in the USA. Previously, Americans only ate to survive and wore clothes to cover their nakedness and not an ounce of thought went into the details beyond this. There was important work to do.
In contrast, the UK has been doing this fashion stuff for a while. Look at how swagged out Henry the 8th was, pic related, and then compare that to boring old George Washington’s dress. Yes he was a royal but even British working class scum are more fashion conscious than their lowly counterparts across the pond. See the tidy and thoughtfully curated fits of the skinheads, or the expensive wardrobes of the ‘casuals’ soccer hooligan subculture…

posts.com:
I feel like Jordan Peterson doesn't actually have any style of his own, he just lets his tailors play dress-up with him and thats how you get ridiculous shit like the twitter suit and elon musk tie.
Even after years of wearing suits for nearly every public appearance, it's like he hasn't pursued any deeper knowledge on dressing well, stuff that you don't hear on a trip to the tailor or menswear department. Some tell-tale signs are:
>he NEVER pays attention to a balanced tie length
>he sometimes wears jackets that are clearly too big
>he ties his ties with large FIH knots almost always, and they often look too thick for the somewhat short collar
>sometimes his collar is garbage-tier stub length
>he almost never wears a shirt that isn't white, which shows that he might not even ever try considering how to pair colors together
>he wears corny, trendy shit like tweed ties with tweed suits
>he once wore a brown suit with black lapels and lapel piping that look straight the fuck out of a bad polyester tuxedo from the 70s or 90s
>he NEVER dimples his fucking tie

He wears suits because of this mentality he has that wearing suits are a symbol of purpose, occasion, and a return to conservatism and formality, which is absolutely not wrong, but he doesn't actually take it further than the surface-level idea of wearing a suit. I highly doubt he's ever read any literature on being well-dressed, or even watched the Gentleman's Gazette, which is a great, easy-to-follow resource for any "well-dressed man" and at any rate a better use of his free time than exposing his brain to ionizing retardation on twitter and debasing himself to the level of your average autistic rightoid reply-guy.

TL:DR: He's the kind of man that doesn't quite "buy" nice clothes as much as he is SOLD nice clothes, and there's an observable difference to anyone with that kind of eye for detail.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17478327
Let’s address the elephant in the room: everything about the watch is retarded. There’s no denying that. It would make a terrible one watch collection. But if you are, say, an anon with a whole collection of wacky shitters who enjoys a lil nonsense, well this makes for a decent addition to the collection.
It’s a Timex from the American Documents line, which is unique in that they’re the only sub 2k watch I could find that have ANY parts made in the US, not including watches with the Ameriquartz movement, which this doesn’t use for no good reason (instead it’s a Ronda, in reference to the hit single “Help Me Rhonda” by America’s band The Beach Boys, surely). The case, hands, dial, strap and mineral glass (in this case, Gorilla Glass) are all made and sourced from the US of A. I think the case and hands are done by an industrial company that doesn’t even make watch parts. I also believe Timex had to convert some spare room into an assembly room for this series. Kinda neat for a Dutch holding company.
What makes this particular model extra unique is that it’s a collaboration with the apparel company MadeWorn, aka some tatted up hipster who fucks up shirts by hand with a blowtorch and sandpaper then charges 200 bucks for it. He also did those custom engraved Rolex abominations you might have seen pictures of floating around the net. Apparently each case, hand and dial are uniquely fucked up, making no two the same.
Pretty neat if you can look past the astronomical price they were originally asking for: 850 smackers, with an original American Documents going for 500. It would take a ridiculous deal for me to satisfy my curiosity for the piece, which is exactly what happened. Timex got me once with a 60% off (rare even for them) Coca Cola Timex Q that I quite like, and they got me again with a very tempting pre tax price tag it 340, less than their currently on sale normal ADs which are at 400 atm, lol…

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17478331
Obviously these weren’t hot sellers. No surprise, as it’s a dress watch that you can’t use in most dressy situations, and a beater with only 30m water resistance. It would take a specific type of retard to be happy with this shitter…
Anyways, onto the watch itself.
>Negatives
Previously mentioned water resistance/formal impracticality
24hr am/pm gmt dial when there’s no gmt hand to be found (AVGN: WHAT WERE THEY THINKING)
Black hands on a half black dial make it very impractical in low light
The hands are split asymmetrically down the middle so it’ll look the hour hand is behind by a couple minutes sometimes, depending on the angle (ocd anons need not apply)
…and you thought fauxtina was obnoxious
>Positives
It’s neato
Ignoring the quirks, the dial is one of Timex’s best
I can’t emphasize enough how unusual a made in USA body is, especially for sub 2k (besides, say, the occasional dude who will make custom Casio cases for 200 hundy and sell them off Instagram)
Very nice, comfortable suede strap from S B Boot Tanning, the dudes that do leather for Red Wing Boots
The finishing is pleasant for what it’s going for, and again, an Amerishart hand finishing something for a watch this cheap is non existent (even if the finishing is more like “fucking up”)
Initial complaints of scratch marks on the other AD watch hands is a non issue here
Initial complaints of the AD watches looking boring is a non issue here
Nice brass case back and crown
Reminds me of Adventureland in Disneyland

Conclusion: I can understand why every sane watch collector and insane member of /wt/ would hate it or simply dismiss it as a costume watch to wear as a steampunk cosplayer to Comic Con. In many ways, you’re correct. On the other hand, it’s a piece that is too weird to live, too rare to die. Thank you for reading my blogpost.
Now please, if you will, roast the shitter to your hearts content.

>>17478327
Welcome to the micro-brand hell.

Only RGM makes a full US movement (defined as made in USA, by mostly USA parts, and by a company owned by Americans.) Everyone else is a micro-brand using Swiss or Jap movements. FTS does not count, fully owned subsidiary of Titan watch, Indian (not native American) company.

Here is a list I made for my own notes:
Vortic, Autodromo, Devon, Shinola, Weiss, RGM, Brew, Kobold, Oak & Oscar, Mercer, Lum-Tec, Timex American Documents series, Keaton Myrick, Dufrane, Throne, Detroit, Pelton, Nodus, Haven, Smith & Bradley, Montana, Schon, Martenero, Astor & Banks, MKII, Padron.

All at least assembled in USA by US owned company.

Just about everything else is US based company making watches in other countries.

Long Island Watch (Ameriquartz used and assembled in USA for some models *including chronograph)

Bertucci (ameriquartz used in some models, most leather straps made in USA)
Waldan (assembled in USA, ameriquartz used in all models)
Shinola (assembled in USA, Swiss quartz assembled in USA in some models)
Weiss (made in USA case, swiss movement customized in USA)
Vortic (made in USA case, antique USA pocket watch movements)
RGM (made in USA case, some movements made in USA)
Detroit Watch Company (assembled in USA)

>>17481304
To be fair, though, >>17481182 is just a screenshot and when anon bought >>17480884 the used price was about 6k USD.

A lot of those supposed "Ultra luxury" brands have such horrific depreciation that you can usually get them used for less than the price of a Rolex Datejust, in perfect condition too, since the story with them usually goes:
>Buyer "needs" a dress watch.
>Buys a ultra-lux watch (not a Patek, though, of course)
>Buyer realizes he never wears the watch because he never gets dressed-up
>Sells watch, takes enormous loss
>Used buyer "needs" a dress watch.
>Used buys a ultra-lux watch (not a Patek, though, of course)
>Used buyer realizes he never wears the watch because he never gets dressed-up
>Sells watch, takes enormous loss
>...
>Some guy buys a ultra-lux watch that's been worn twice for 5k USD.

tl;dr: ultra-luxury watches are great, but if your collection doesn't have a Daytona or GMT-IIc you're not fooling anyone.

no, dont feel bad for buying chrome reps. i have a small collection of all real (from la and malibu) chrome jewelry but some of the reps are scary close, and besides if they are both silver theres not much difference. in terms of my opinoins on th brand:

> jewelry

>"merch" (t's, sweatshirts, hoodies, etc

incredibly based. my mom has a pair of the glasses and the quality is ridiculous. blows any other pair of glasses ive ever seen out of the water.

>actual apparel
leather jackets and things like fluer knee pants are sick. anything leather with lots of hardwear is bread and butter for chrome. this stuff stands on its own compared to the shitty logo ts

>other - furniture, accessories, random objects
in my opinion, the random shit that chrome hearts makes is a big draw to the brand. the fact that the stores are entirely on them, down to the chrome hearts ebony wood dining tables, chairs, cabinent hardwear, etc really set chrome apart and sort of help justify their utterly insane pricing. this is part of the reason why i am a fan of the brand, and will continue to be long after hypebeasts move on to the next trendy logo tee.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17475533
There arent any good pieces of clothing in vintage stores here in the uk. The european high quality stuff is expensive here, the american high quality stuff is expensive here and the uk manufactured stuff is all fast fashion tat.

Its all overpriced stinky ralph lauren and tommy hillfiger shirts, a few old levis jeans sprinkled in with a couple of old gildan jumpers with some 'retro' print on them. There aren't actually any high or even any mid tier fashion brands found in thrift stores. Everything of value is on ebay or grailed and seems to hold it's value. USA has relatively high quality heritage outdoor brands like carhartt, filson, patagonia, penfield, columbia, nautica (to an extent) as well as the skater brands like stussy that can be found at bottom dollar at thrift stores. Here in the UK that stuff is imported and seems to hold it's value a lot more in stores. You'll see a thrift store selling some 'vintage' champion hoody for like 30gbp+ over here as a standard. For that kind of money you can just get a new hoody.

I find the best way to find bargains for high end brands is go to ebay and search for lesser known high-mid fashion brands and filter to ending soonest. I open Mr porter, go through their brandlist and just copy/paste a lot of them in to ebay and see what comes up. The more popular stuff like apc, norse projects, fjallraven goes for quite a bit (although it does go for cheap sometimes) but you'll get some lesser known brand for nearly nothing with the quality still being very good. Like you can end up getting a 200+gbp jumper or jacket regularly for 1/10th of the price.
